displayed_text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession?

answer.text_box: My opinion is that if it's something they love to do and it brings them happiness, then I have no issues with it. So long as they are not doing anything illegal, it's just another job in this world to me.

displayed_text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Based on the comments provided, here is an overall summary of the opinions on internet influencers becoming a recognized profession:

Opinions on internet influencers becoming a recognized profession are diverse, ranging from strong support to significant criticism, with many holding a nuanced or mixed view.

A considerable portion of commentators view the rise of influencers positively, seeing it as a valid and modern form of entrepreneurship. They appreciate that it allows individuals to earn a living doing something they enjoy, often from the convenience of their own homes. Supporters see influencers as the new wave of media, providing valuable entertainment, information, product recommendations, and news that might not be covered by traditional outlets. This perspective frames influencing as a democratization of media, where everyday people can build a platform, connect with audiences in a relatable way, and shape cultural trends.

Conversely, a notable group expresses negative sentiment, finding influencers to be annoying, inauthentic, and attention-seeking. These critics worry about the societal impact, suggesting that the profession promotes overconsumption, misinformation, and a culture of self-obsession, with one person comparing the phenomenon to the "Tower of Babel." There are also concerns that it presents an unrealistic or undesirable career path for young people, encouraging them to pursue "easy money" over traditional education or more substantive careers.

Many comments fall in a middle ground, acknowledging the reality of influencing as a profession while pointing out its complexities and drawbacks. These individuals recognize it as a natural evolution of media and commerce in the digital age. They often concede that the work is more difficult than it appears and that the market is becoming oversaturated. A recurring theme in this balanced view is the call for responsibility and accountability. Many believe that because influencers have the power to shape opinions and behaviors, they must be held to higher standards of transparency and authenticity, much like other professions.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments

  • Sentiment: Views are mixed but lean moderately positive. Roughly 60–70% regard influencing as a valid or promising profession (often with caveats about ethics and sustainability), about 20–30% are critical or dismissive, and the remainder are neutral or conflicted.

  • Perceived benefits:

  • Legitimate career path and natural evolution of media and marketing; democratizes who can build an audience and earn independently.
  • Offers flexibility, entrepreneurship, and multiple income streams; can open doors and create new kinds of jobs.
  • Provides entertainment, product discovery, and sometimes high-quality, niche, or faster-to-market information; some see creators as “new media houses” that can supplement or challenge traditional news.

  • Competition can improve content quality and accuracy over time.

  • Main concerns and criticisms:

  • Oversaturation and sustainability: success is rare, luck-driven, and volatile; many see it as better as a side gig than a main career.
  • Authenticity and ethics: perceived fakeness, grifting, and pay-to-promote dynamics; pressure to be outrageous; parasocial dynamics.
  • Misinformation and lack of standards: riskier when audiences rely on influencers as their sole news source.
  • Social impact: unrealistic expectations for youth, devaluing traditional careers, homogenized trends, overconsumption, and mental health concerns for both creators and audiences.

  • Accountability and transparency gaps compared to regulated professions.

  • Conditions many attach to acceptance:

  • Clear disclosure of sponsorships and AI use, fact-checking, and responsible behavior toward audiences.
  • Media literacy education, especially for younger audiences.
  • Greater professionalization: ethics guidelines, platform transparency, fair contracts, and creator safety nets.

  • Diversification of content and income, and not positioning influencer content as the only news source.

  • Broader context and trends:

  • Growth accelerated in recent years (notably during lockdowns); shift from TV to social platforms; sponsorships reshaped advertising.
  • Influencers are often compared to entertainers or small business owners—part performer, part marketer.
  • Outlook: continued normalization and impact on culture and commerce, with ongoing tension around authenticity, regulation, and long-term viability.
